abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The azalea lace bug <jats:italic>Stephanitis</jats:italic> (<jats:italic>Stephanitis</jats:italic>) <jats:italic>pyrioides</jats:italic> (Scott, 1874) (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Tingidae) originates from the East Palaearctic. In 2020, this alien species was recorded for the first time in the European part of Russia (Krasnodar Territory, Sochi), notably attacking <jats:italic>Rhododendron</jats:italic> × <jats:italic>hybridum</jats:italic> hort. It most likely arrived there with plants for planting from Italy. The main morphological characteristics of adults and larvae are described and illustrated. The morphological differences between <jats:italic>S. pyrioides</jats:italic> and closely related <jats:italic>S. pyri</jats:italic> (Fabricius, 1775) are highlighted in the key to distinguish these two species, bearing in mind that now both of them can be found in the south of the European part of Russia. Additionally, DNA barcoding data for <jats:italic>S. pyrioides</jats:italic> from Sochi were analysed against other related species of <jats:italic>Stephanitis</jats:italic> whose DNA barcodes are available in Barcode of Life Data Systems (BOLD) and GenBank: <jats:italic>S. takeyai</jats:italic> Drake et Maa, 1955, <jats:italic>S. oberti</jats:italic> (Kolenati, 1857), <jats:italic>S. mendica</jats:italic> Horváth, 1912, and <jats:italic>S. chinensis</jats:italic> Drake, 1948. The bionomics, distribution, damage and impact of <jats:italic>S. pyrioides</jats:italic> are outlined.</jats:p>
title: First record of the azalea lace bug Stephanitis pyrioides (Scott, 1874) (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Tingidae) in the European part of Russia: Molecular genetics and taxonomy of an alien pest
